sen.j: 十輪院（じゅうりんいん）は奈良県奈良市十輪院町にある真言宗醍醐派の寺院である。
sen.e: Jurin-in Temple, located in Jurin-in Town, Nara City, Nara Prefecture is a temple that belongs to the Daigo school of the Shingon sect.
Jurin-in Temple, located in Jurin-in Town, Nara City, Nara Prefecture, is a temple that belongs to the Daigo school of the Shingon sect.
Jurin-in Temple, located in Jurin-in Town, Nara City, Nara Prefecture, is a temple that belongs to the Daigo school of the Shingon sect.

sen.j: 山号は雨宝山。
sen.e: Its sango (literally "mountain name", a title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Uho-san Mountain.
Its sango (literally "mountain name", a title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Uho-san Mountain.
Its sango (literally "mountain name", a title prefixed to the name of a Buddhist temple) is Uho-san Mountain.

sen.j: 本尊は石造の地蔵菩薩。
sen.e: Its principle image is a stone Jizo Bosatsu (Ksitigarbha).
Its principle image is a stone Jizo Bosatsu of Ksitigarbha.
Its principle image is a stone Jizo Bosatsu of Ksitigarbha.

sen.j: 開基（創立者）は朝野魚養（あさののなかい）と伝える。
sen.e: It is said to have been founded by ASANO no Nakai.
It is said to have been founded by ASANO no Nakai.
It is said to have been founded by ASANO no Nakai.

sen.j: 江戸・明治期の町並みが残るならまちの一角に位置する。
sen.e: It is located in a corner of a town which still has the townscape of the Edo and Meiji periods.
It is located in a corner of the town which retains many buildings of the Edo and Meiji periods.
It is located in a corner of the town which retains many buildings of the Edo and Meiji periods.

sen.j: もとは大寺院だった元興寺の別院とされ、寺伝によると奈良時代に右大臣・吉備真備（きびのまきび）の長男である朝野魚養（あさのなかい）が、元正天皇の旧殿を拝領し創建したと伝わる。
sen.e: It was originally an annex of the larger temple called Gango-ji Temple, and according to temple legend ASANO no Nakai, eldest son to the Minister of the Right KIBI no Makibi, received Empress Gensho's old palace and rebuilt it as a temple in the Nara period.

It was originally an annex of a larger temple called Gango-ji Temple, and according to temple legend ASANO no Nakai, the eldest son of the Minister of the Right KIBI no Makibi, received Empress Gensho's former palace and rebuilt it as a temple in the Nara Period.

It was originally an annex of a larger temple called Gango-ji Temple, and according to temple legend ASANO no Nakai, the eldest son of the Minister of the Right KIBI no Makibi, received Empress Gensho's former palace and rebuilt it as a temple in the Nara Period.

sen.j: 中世以降は庶民の地蔵信仰の寺として栄えた。
sen.e: After the medieval period it prospered as a temple for jizo (Ksitigarbha or guardian deity) worship by the common people.
After the medieval period it prospered as a temple for jizo (Ksitigarbha or guardian deity) worship by the common people.
After the medieval period it prospered as a temple for jizo (Ksitigarbha or guardian deity) worship by the common people.

sen.j: 朝野魚養は能書（書道の名人）とされ、空海の書の師ともいうが、伝記のはっきりしない人物である。
sen.e: ASANO no Nakai is said to have been a master of calligraphy and Kukai's calligraphy teacher, but his history is unclear.
ASANO no Nakai is said to have been a master of calligraphy and Kukai's calligraphy teacher, but details of his life are unclear.
ASANO no Nakai is said to have been a master of calligraphy and Kukai's calligraphy teacher, but details of his life are unclear.

sen.j: 十輪院については、『大和名所記（和州旧跡幽考）』のような近世の地誌類には弘法大師（空海）の創建とも伝え、創建の正確な時期や事情については不明である。
sen.e: Regarding Jyurin-in Temple, in modern local reports such as "Yamato Meishoki (Washu Kyuseki Yuko)" (Yamato Guide to Notable Places) it is also told that it was established by Kobo Daishi (Kukai), and the accurate time or circumstances surrounding its establishment is unclear.

Modern works such as "Yamato Meishoki (Washu Kyuseki Yuko)" (Yamato Guide to Notable Places) relate that Jurin-in Temple was established by Kobo Daishi (Kukai), but the accurate time and circumstances surrounding its establishment are unclear.
sen.cmt: Word order, spelling, grammar, punctuation, changed for clarity.
sen.e: Modern works such as "Yamato Meishoki (Washu Kyuseki Yuko)" (Yamato Guide to Notable Places) relate that Jurin-in Temple was established by Kobo Daishi (Kukai), but the accurate time and circumstances surrounding its establishment are unclear.

sen.j: 「十輪院」の名称の文献上の初見は、鎌倉時代の仏教説話集『沙石集』（弘安6年・1283年成立）とされている。
sen.e: The first appearance of the name Jyurin-in Temple in literature is said to be in the collection of Buddhist stories from the Kamakura period, Shasekishu (established 1283).
The first appearance of the name Jurin-in Temple in literature is said to be in the collection of Buddhist stories from the Kamakura Period, Shasekishu (composed 1283).
The first appearance of the name Jurin-in Temple in literature is said to be in the collection of Buddhist stories from the Kamakura Period, Shasekishu (composed 1283).

sen.j: 現存する本堂、石仏龕（せきぶつがん）、東京へ移築された宝蔵などはいずれも正確な年代は不明ながら鎌倉時代のものとされており、鎌倉時代には地蔵信仰の寺院として栄えていたと思われる。
sen.e: Although the accurate dates are uncertain, the existing hondo (main building), Sekibutsugan (stone Buddhist altar) and treasury which was relocated to Tokyo are all said to be from the Kamakura period, and it is thought that Jyurin-in Temple prospered as a place for jizo worship in the Kamakura period.

Although the accurate dates are uncertain, the existing hondo (main building), the sekibutsugan (stone Buddhist altar) and the treasury (which was relocated to Tokyo) are all considered to be from the Kamakura Period, and it is thought that Jurin-in Temple prospered as a place for jizo worship during the Kamakura Period.

Although the accurate dates are uncertain, the existing hondo (main building), the sekibutsugan (stone Buddhist altar) and the treasury (which was relocated to Tokyo) are all considered to be from the Kamakura Period, and it is thought that Jurin-in Temple prospered as a place for jizo worship during the Kamakura Period.

sen.j: 本堂（国宝）－背後の覆堂内に安置された石仏龕を拝むための礼堂として建立された鎌倉時代の住宅風仏堂。
sen.e: Hondo (national treasure) – Residential style Buddhist temple of the Kamakura period, built as a prayer hall to worship the Sekibutsugan placed within the sheltering hall located behind.
The hondo (a National Treasure) is a residential style Buddhist temple of the Kamakura Period, built as a prayer hall to worship the sekibutsugan placed within the sheltering hall located behind.
sen.cmt: Made into a sentence, grammar, punctuation.
sen.e: The hondo (a National Treasure) is a residential style Buddhist temple of the Kamakura Period, built as a prayer hall to worship the sekibutsugan placed within the sheltering hall located behind.

sen.j: 寄棟造、本瓦葺き。
sen.e: Rectangular building with hip-and-gable roofing.
It is a rectangular building with hip-and-gable roofing.
It is a rectangular building with hip-and-gable roofing.

sen.j: 建物全体の立ちが低く、正面は広縁の奥に蔀戸（しとみど）を設け、全体として住宅風の意匠になる。
sen.e: The building itself stands low throughout, with latticed shutters past the veranda at the front and an overall design which is very residential-like.
The building is low throughout, with latticed shutters above the veranda at the front and an overall design which is very residential in style.
The building is low throughout, with latticed shutters above the veranda at the front and an overall design which is very residential in style.

sen.j: 軒裏に垂木（たるき）を用いず板軒とする点も一般の仏堂建築と異なる特色である。
sen.e: The use of wide boards at the underside of the roof rather than the rafters is also a characteristic that differs from general Buddhist temple architecture.
The use of wide boards for the underside of the roof rather than the rafters is also a characteristic that differs from general Buddhist temple architecture.
The use of wide boards for the underside of the roof rather than the rafters is also a characteristic that differs from general Buddhist temple architecture.

sen.j: 御影堂（奈良県指定文化財） - 1650年（慶安3年、江戸時代）の建築
sen.e: Goei-do Hall (hall dedicated to the sect's founder) (cultural property designated by Nara Prefecture) – Constructed in 1650
The Goei-do Hall (a hall dedicated to the sect's founder), a cultural property designated by Nara Prefecture, was constructed in 1650
The Goei-do Hall (a hall dedicated to the sect's founder), a cultural property designated by Nara Prefecture, was constructed in 1650

sen.j: 護摩堂
sen.e: Goma-do Hall (hall for the goma rites)
The Goma-do Hall is a hall where the goma rites take place.
The Goma-do Hall is a hall where the goma rites take place.

sen.j: 南門（重要文化財）- 切妻造・本瓦葺の四脚門。
sen.e: South Gate (important cultural property) – 4-pillar gate with hip-and-gable roofing.
The South Gate (an Important Cultural Property) is a four-pillar gate with hip-and-gable roofing.
The South Gate (an Important Cultural Property) is a four-pillar gate with hip-and-gable roofing.

sen.j: 四脚門、鎌倉時代建築
sen.e: 4-pillar gate, constructed in the Kamakura period
This four-pillar gate was also constructed in the Kamakura Period
This four-pillar gate was also constructed in the Kamakura Period

sen.j: なお、東京国立博物館構内にある「旧十輪院宝蔵」（重要文化財）は、もとこの寺にあり、明治15年（1882年）に東京へ移築されたものである。
sen.e: The 'Old Jurin-in Temple Treasury' (important cultural property) housed within the Tokyo National Museum was originally located at this temple, and was relocated to Tokyo in 1882.
The 'Old Jurin-in Temple Treasury' (an Important Cultural Property) housed within the Tokyo National Museum was originally located at this temple, and was relocated to Tokyo in 1882.
The 'Old Jurin-in Temple Treasury' (an Important Cultural Property) housed within the Tokyo National Museum was originally located at this temple, and was relocated to Tokyo in 1882.

sen.j: 小規模な校倉造倉庫で、鎌倉時代の建築である。
sen.e: It is a small-scale Azekura-zukuri style warehouse constructed in the Kamakura period.
It is a small-scale Azekura-zukuri style warehouse constructed in the Kamakura Period.
It is a small-scale Azekura-zukuri style warehouse constructed in the Kamakura Period.

sen.j: 本堂 - 既述
sen.e: Hondo – Mentioned above
The hondo, as mentioned above.
The hondo, as mentioned above.

sen.j: 南門
sen.e: South Gate
South Gate
South Gate

sen.j: 石仏龕（附覆堂）－すべて花崗岩の切石を用いた日本では非常に珍しい石仏龕。
sen.e: Sekibutsugan (within the sheltering hall) – A stone Buddhist altar made completely with cut granite, which makes it extremely rare in Japan.
The sekibutsugan (kept inside the sheltering hall) is a stone Buddhist altar made completely out of granite, which is extremely rare in Japan.
The sekibutsugan (kept inside the sheltering hall) is a stone Buddhist altar made completely out of granite, which is extremely rare in Japan.

sen.j: 間口3メートル、奥行2.5メートル、高さ2.3メートルの規模で、地蔵菩薩立像を中心に、その手前左右の壁面に冥界の十王像、その手前左右には弥勒菩薩、釈迦如来、不動明王、観音菩薩を表わし、さらに外側には五輪塔や持国天、多聞天、金剛力士（仁王）などの像を表わす。
sen.e: The dimensions are 3m (entry width) by 2.5m (depth) by 2.3m (height); a standing Jizo Bosatsu statue is in the center, and around are statues of the ten underworld kings along the walls to the left and right, and in front of those Miroku Bosatsu, Shaka Nyorai, Fudo Myoo and Kannon Bosatsu are depicted, and further outside statues of Gorinto (5-level pagoda), Jikokuten (Dhrtarastra), Tamonten (Vaisravana) and Kongo Rishiki (Nio) are presented.

It is 3m wide by 2.5m deep by 2.3m high; a Jizo Bosatsu statue is in the center, and around it are statues of the ten underworld kings positioned along the walls to the left and right, and in front of these statues depict Miroku Bosatsu, Shaka Nyorai, Fudo Myoo and Kannon Bosatsu, and further outside the arrangement statues of a gorinto (five-level pagoda), Jikokuten (Dhrtarastra), Tamonten (Vaisravana) and Kongo Rishiki (Nio) are displayed.
sen.cmt: Changed for clarity, style, grammar, punctuation.
sen.e: It is 3m wide by 2.5m deep by 2.3m high; a Jizo Bosatsu statue is in the center, and around it are statues of the ten underworld kings positioned along the walls to the left and right, and in front of these statues depict Miroku Bosatsu, Shaka Nyorai, Fudo Myoo and Kannon Bosatsu, and further outside the arrangement statues of a gorinto (five-level pagoda), Jikokuten (Dhrtarastra), Tamonten (Vaisravana) and Kongo Rishiki (Nio) are displayed.

sen.j: 地蔵菩薩像は鎌倉時代前期頃、他の諸像はやや時代が降るとされている。
sen.e: The Jizo Bosatsu statue is from early Kamakura period, and the other statues are from a somewhat later time.
The Jizo Bosatsu statue is from the early Kamakura Period, and the other statues are from a somewhat later time.
The Jizo Bosatsu statue is from the early Kamakura Period, and the other statues are from a somewhat later time.

sen.j: なお、この石仏龕は「彫刻」ではなく「建造物」として重要文化財に指定されている。
sen.e: This sekibutsugan has been designated as an important cultural property not as a sculpture, but as architecture.
This sekibutsugan has been designated as an Important Cultural Property, not as a sculpture, but as architecture.
This sekibutsugan has been designated as an Important Cultural Property, not as a sculpture, but as architecture.

sen.j: 木造不動明王二童子立像 - 護摩堂安置。
sen.e: Wooden statue of standing Fudo Myoo with two children - Placed in the Goma-do Hall.
There is also a wooden statue of Fudo Myoo with two children located in the Goma-do Hall.

sen.j: 平安時代後期。

sen.j: 河島英五の墓はここにある。
sen.e: Eigo KAWASHIMA's tomb is located here.

sen.j: JR大和路線奈良駅・近鉄奈良駅より奈良交通バス（天理駅行）「福智院町」下車、徒歩
sen.e: From JR Yamatoji line Nara Station or Kintetsu Nara Station take Nara Kotsu bus (for Tenri station), and walk from Fukuchiin-cho bus stop.
